title: FDA papers for class
description: I briefly read a few papers on functional data analysis that I need to read for a class assignment. Hopefully the class assignment will be a paper eventually as well.
contents:
Today, I am unfortunately plagued by required reading, rather than
continuing to attack my ‚Äúto-read‚Äù pile on my desk. I didn‚Äôt read these
papers in complete detail, but rather skimmed over both of them.

Woldu H et al., Applying functional data analysis to assess
tele-interpersonal psychotherapy‚Äôs efficacy to reduce depression.
Journal of Applied Statistics. 2019;46(2):203-216.


Yao F, M√ºller H, Wang J. Functional data analysis for sparse
longitudinal data. Journal of the American Statistical
Association. 2005;100(470):577-590.

Some background on why I need to read these! I‚Äôm currently taking a
course on ‚ÄúAdvanced Biostatistics‚Äù which is essentially about reading
biostatistical literature and applying the concepts, rather than just
applying things from textbooks. For my course project, I‚Äôm reanalyzing
some flu vaccine data (HAI titers over time) using functional data
analysis techniques rather than hierarchical linear models. The main
hurdle with this is that I do not know anything about functional data
analysis, which is why I need to read about it. The first citation I‚Äôve
listed is by a former student in my program, who actually took the same
class as me, and is a pretty readable implementation of some FDA
methods. However, the data that I have are sparser than the data used in
this paper, so I also looked at the second citation to get an idea for
what methods are appropriate for sparse longitudinal data (I only have
two measurements per year).
While I‚Äôm normally not a fan of really complicated frequentist
methods, there are a few points that I like about FDA enumerated in the
Woldu paper. FDA doesn‚Äôt require specification of a covariance
structure, and also ‚Äúautomatically controls‚Äù for measurement error in a
specific way. HAI titers are known to be subjective, and especially when
not conducted with replicates, HAI data can often be subject to
measurement error. FDA techniques deal with that by ‚Äúsmoothing‚Äù the
data‚Äìfrom the time series of observations, a smoothed curve is
constructed for analysis, typically using b-splines. This smoothing is
the first step where I think most FDA methods depart from reality‚Äìno
true data generating process uses b-splines in the wild. But b-splines
are often a good approximation of smooth patterns. Influenza
strain-specific serum antibody titer IS a ‚Äúsmooth‚Äù curve (of course no
biological curve is smooth if you look at a small enough time scale),
and HAI titer is a discrete surrogate for antibody titer. Of course it
isn‚Äôt a perfect measurement, but the literature does suggest that HAI
titer is a correlate for influenza protection, and it‚Äôs easier and
cheaper than other assays. So I think that using a b-spline
approximation to get smooth functions is ok.
However, the second paper, on sparse data, says that although a
former paper suggested a type of mixed-effects model with a b-spline
basis for sparse longitudinal data, they ‚Äú[represented] the trajectories
directly through the Karhunen-Lo√®ve expansion.‚Äù I was hoping to avoid
dealing with this, as I do not understand the KL expansion at all.
Notably, they dislike the previous paper using bootstrap for pointwise
confidence intervals. I think the nonparametric bootstrap could probably
be used in a way to get a CI for the whole curve (either by resampling
individuals to include in the KL expansion or by resampling weights for
the expansion somehow), but I‚Äôm never convinced that parametric
intervals are better than bootstrap. Particularly, some of the
asymptotic results derived in this paper depend on assumptions of
normality ‚Äì I find this interesting as the Waldu paper claims that FDA
techniques do not require a normality assumption for random effects.
Maybe this is only true for ‚Äúdense-enough‚Äù data.
However, as I continued reading the second paper, this is when I
became wary. The authors‚Äô proposed solution for functional data is PACE.
PACE is capitalized throughout the paper, but I can‚Äôt figure out what it
stands for. However, it is a type of functional principal components
analysis for sparse functional data. I do not like principal components
and I will never like principal components. I think PCA is fine for
predictive modeling where the explanations aren‚Äôt really relevant, but
in exploratory and causal modeling, PCA is often a tool for avoiding
critical thinking. I think that in 99% of cases when applied, PCA
provides very little (if any) useful information. However, I don‚Äôt know
that much about functional PCA so maybe it will surprise me.
The rest of the first paper is a description of the methods used,
followed by interpretation of the results. Essentially, the paper
applies smoothing methods, functional PCA, and functional regression,
which is essentially what I plan to do for my analysis. The authors of
the second paper have also written another paper:

Yao F, M√ºller H, Wang J. Functional linear regression analysis for
longitudinal data. The Annals of Statistics.
2005;22(6):2873-2903.

This paper talks about functional regression methods extended to
sparse functional data, so I guess I will need to glance over that paper
as well. I would also be interested in finding more ‚Äúapplied‚Äù papers
that apply and interpret these papers, like the Woldu paper I read
today. In addition to the PCA analysis, which Woldu interprets quite
well (well, as much as PCA can be interpreted), I want to try two
regression methods. One method would be a functional response with
non-functional covariates, where the pre-vaccination and
post-vaccination HAI titers are all included in the smoothed trajectory.
I‚Äôd also like to try a function-on-function regression model, where the
post-vaccination trajectories are used to create smoothed curves, which
include a smoothed curve of the pre-vaccination trajectory (and also
other covariates) as predictors.
I‚Äôm not going to go into detail about the theory and methods in these
papers in this post, like I said earlier I‚Äôm mostly skimming these to
get an idea of what FDA is and how I can use it. After I changed my PhD
concentration to data analysis and modeling instead of biostatistics, I
don‚Äôt have to worry so much about theorems and lemmas anymore üòÅ. I also
am trying to spend an hour or less on these posts per day, unless the
paper is really important to my other current goals, so I guess that‚Äôs
all I‚Äôll write about FDA. Hopefully I‚Äôll get to work on the actual
analysis soon!

title: Welcome to my blog!
description: This is my first blog post. I created this to make sure I know how to make a blog post.
contents:
Motivation: one of my bad habits as a PhD student so far has been not
reading any papers, then whenever it‚Äôs time to work on something,
reading 100 abstracts at one time and only the papers that seem the most
important. I‚Äôve decided to work on that by attempting to read a paper a
day. Every day when I come to the office, the first thing I will do is
read a paper.
I currently have a backlog of printed-out papers to read, so I‚Äôll try
and get through those first unless something really catches my
attention. I‚Äôll be as strict as I can, but some days I know I just won‚Äôt
have time (I run into a lot of time crunches recently‚Ä¶) and some days
I‚Äôll probably read more than one paper. Maybe I‚Äôll make two blog posts
on those days.
I read somewhere that one of the best ways to remember the take-home
points of a paper is to write down a summary with your thoughts
immediately after reading (and annotating!) the paper, so that was the
impetus for this blog.
Maybe at some point I‚Äôll figure out how to set up comments on this
blog (I bet Alison Hill has a blog post about how to do it) but for now,
if you want to get in touch with me to tell me how much you love my blog
or that I completely misinterpreted your paper, go back to my main site and get
my contact info there.

title: 2022-04-08: Immune imprinting and epitope masking!
description:
Today I read 'Influenza immunization in the context of preexisting immunity' by
Linderman et al. from Cold Spring Harbor Perspectives in Medicine (2021). This
review discusses how influenza vaccines can induce different immune responses
based on an individual's immune profile prior to vaccination. A few mechanisms
and previous results explaining this phenomenon are discussed, including
immune imprinting and epitope masking.
contents:
The paper I read today is:

Linderman, Susanne L., Ali H. Ellebedy, Carl Davis, Christiane S.
Eberhardt, Rustom Antia, Rafi Ahmed, and Veronika I. Zarnitsyna.
‚ÄúInfluenza Immunization in the Context of Preexisting Immunity.‚Äù Cold
Spring Harbor Perspectives in Medicine, September 28, 2020, a040964. https://doi.org/10.1101/cshperspect.a040964.

My main research focus right now is on how characteristics of
individuals and characteristics of virus strains can work together to
effect the immune response to the seasonal flu vaccine, so this review
is something I‚Äôve been meaning to get to for a while. I‚Äôve already read
a lot of the constituent citations, but at some point I plan to reread
them and input my thoughts here. Maybe it will help me remember them
better.
In general, immunologists have pretty good proof that immunity to
influenza is (at least partially) ‚Äúpath dependent.‚Äù The so-called
immune profile1 of an individual is
affected by the strains of influenza they are exposed to, as one would
likely expect. An individual infected with a specific strain of
influenza will likely have a memory immune response to that strain.
However, an individual who is infected with H1N1 then H3N2 later will
have an immune profile that is quite different from an individual who is
infected with H3N2 then H1N1 later! In general, prior immunity to one
strain tends to shape the individual‚Äôs immune response to future
strains. This phenomenon is called ‚Äúoriginal antigenic sin‚Äù
immune imprinting.
The main conclusions supported by the review are: preexisting
immunity somehow inhibits the ability to mount an immune response to a
novel strain of the same pathogen; memory recall responses to conserved
epitopes or that bind weakly to antigenically drifted epitopes are at
least partially responsible; preexisting antibody titers inhibit the
magnitude of the antibody response; high antibody titers for specific
epitopes can lead to an immune response where another antibody is
immunodominant; and epitope masking, where antibody binding to antigen
inhibits the activation of the memory B-cell response, is a potential
explanation for the boosting of responses to different epitopes.
The conclusions that preexisting immunity often inhibits the immune
response to drifted flu strains, and that the memory B cell response is
a cause of this phenomenon were not new to me. Although I still don‚Äôt
really know what I‚Äôm talking about, I knew that clonal selection of
B-cells leads to memory B cells with high affinity for antigen ‚Äì so
similar antigens can activate the memory response, which makes mounting
a novel response more difficult. The relationship between fold change in
antibodies and preexisting immunity is quite interesting to me ‚Äì I have
been working with serological data where I see this exact pattern, and
part of my current research is about this specific phenomenon. I think
the patterns of boosting and the explanation of epitope masking are
interesting, but like with all mathematical models, I think explicit
biological studies are necessary to confirm the findings. While the
mathematical models which support epitope masking as an explanation for
boosting to different epitopes are interesting, unless lab data can show
that epitope masking or steric hinderance is possible and actually
occurring in this case, I‚Äôm not ready to believe that it is the sole
cause of this phenomenon.
I‚Äôm also primarily interested in the seasonal influenza vaccine,
where most boosting events are not to novel strains, but instead to
antigenically drifted strains which (in the grand scheme of things) are
not that different. Both the original source paper and the review note
that epitope masking may not explain the ability of prevaccination
immunity to an antigenically different, but similar, strain to inhibit
the formation of a novel immune response. Although it seems biologically
plausible to me that the memory B cell response is playing a large role
in the inhibition of a novel response.
It sort of took me all day to read this review. It is fairly dense
and I kept getting interrupted by my thoughts and other things, so it
took me a while to read. So my thoughts in this post are probably quite
choppy and not super cogent. But overall, I was already aware of most of
the work that went into this review, but I am glad to have all of the
information summarized in one place. The review also talks a lot about
stem vs.¬†head antibody, but most of the data that is available to me
does not measure stem antibody (in fact, they only measure HAI titers,
which is another issue altogether). However, I suspect that I will be
reading through this paper‚Äôs entire bibliography in the near
feature.
